Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Carolina Cyber Defender Scholarship

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Carolina Cyber Defender Scholarship program is jointly offered by the University of North Carolina at Charlotte, NC A&T State University, and Johnson C. Smith University. This program prepares students to become intellectual leaders in cybersecurity. Students can pursue baccalaureate, masters as well as doctoral studies. Scholarship students engage in rigorous academic programs that emphasize both theory and practice of cybersecurity and incorporate research and experiential learning.

Each scholarship student is required to contribute to one of many cutting edge research projects led by experienced professors and develop capabilities in critical thinking, problem formulation and problem solving. The program has a rich set of extracurricular activities including frequent seminar speakers from industry and academia as well as participation in national and international hands-on cybersecurity competitions. Professional development, including effective communication as well as leadership, is emphasized. The curriculum covers a broad spectrum of cybersecurity topics including network security, configuration security, penetration testing, software assurance, data privacy, mobile and wireless security, usable security, access and identity management, computer forensics, policy and governance, security risk management, and cryptography.

The scholarship program is aimed at creating a cadre of diverse cyber security professionals to address the nation's critical need for talent in key national security as well as critical infrastructure protection positions.

Institution.Name: North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NORTH CAROLINA AGRICULTURAL AND TECHNICAL STATE UNIVERSITY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at North Carolina A&T State University (NC A&T) supported thirty-eight students between Fall 2012 and Spring 2017. Thirty-five of them are Aferican-American, Sixteen of them are female. Two of them are Ph.D students. Thirty-one of them graduated and received Master Science degree. The SFS receipients worked on a wide variety of research projects in cybersecurity. They have published over twenty-three papers in journals and conferences. Graduated students have been successfully placed in Federal, State, and Local government jobs approved by the Office of the Personnel Management. As a result, this program greatly improves diversity among cybersecurity professionals.

NC A&T completed a cybersecurity curriculum recognized by the NSA/DHS as a Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education Cyber Defense. NC A&T collaborated with University of North Carolina (UNC) at Charlotte for this project. Our students received 3rd place in the Captured Flag Competition at UNC Charlotte. This collaboration also led to substantial curriculum improvements including launching of the Ph.D program in cybersecurity.

According to a survey conducted in 2016, 90% of graduates indicated that the program prepared them for a cubersecurity career, 95% said it advanced their knowledge in cybersecurity, 90% reported the program provided professional networking opportunities, and 94% reported overall satisfaction with the program,
